description: Compare Scots clatch (“a slap, the noise caused by the collision of soft bodies”); probably of imitative origin.

entries.meaning: (UK, Scotland, dialect) A soft or sloppy lump or mass.
examples: to throw a clatch of mud

entries.meaning: (UK, Scotland, dialect) Anything put together or made in a careless or slipshod way.
(UK, Scotland, dialect, by extension) A sluttish or slipshod woman.
(UK, Scotland, dialect, historical) A kind of gig.

verbs.description: clatch (third-person singular simple present clatches, present participle clatching, simple past and past participle clatched)

entries.meaning: (UK, Scotland, dialect, transitive, intransitive) To daub or smear, as with lime; to make or finish in a slipshod way.
